utterance.speaker: Dr. Brian Greene
utterance.content: My new book, The Hidden Reality, takes on a grand question. Is our universe the only universe? You see, there’s a growing belief among scientists like me that ours may only be one among many universes populating a gigantic cosmos. In The Hidden Reality, I explore this possibility without presuming any knowledge of mathematics or physics on the part of the reader.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hysterical.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m glad you talked me into this. We work so hard, sometimes, it’s nice to goof off and do something silly.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Agreed. Wait till you hear how he dumbs down Werner Heisenberg for the crowd. You may actually believe you’re in a comedy club.

utterance.speaker: Greene
utterance.content: You can think about Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle much like the special order menu that you find in certain Chinese restaurants, where you have dishes in column A and other dishes in column B, and if you order the first dish in column A, you can’t order the corresponding dish in column B. That’s sort of like the Uncertainly Principle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ba-dum-bump.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Say, I heard an interesting tidbit about Howard and Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really, Amy? Gossip? I’m disappointed in you.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Now, now. Evolutionary biologist Robin Dunbar has identified gossip as an aid to social bonding in large groups.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Forgive my language, but poppycock.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What if he’s right? And by not participating in gossip, society breaks down into small feral bands of tattooed motorcycle riders fighting to the death over the last few cans of tuna fish?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Bernadette is thinking about breaking up with Howard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I believe our nation’s tuna cans are safe. Excuse me. Dr. Greene, question?

utterance.speaker: Greene
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon

utterance.speaker: Greene

utterance.speaker: Greene

utterance.content: Nice shot.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you. My father taught me archery as a child. It’s odd how the activity brings back the smell of Kmart bourbon.

utterance.content: Leonard, the people at Nintendo can only go so far in helping us recreate an actual athletic experience. We have to do our part, too. That was uncalled for, but I’ll play along. Ow! I had an unusual experience with Amy last night.

utterance.content: Okay, we’re getting off the subject. Rajesh, I want you to try harder to make your sister feel welcome.

utterance.speaker: Raj

utterance.speaker: Priya

utterance.speaker: Priya

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fair enough. Now, what’s up with Clarinet? Bernadette!

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s all. I’ve just been thinking about it. Now, I’m thinking about fractal equations. Now I’m thinking about the origin of the phrase train of thought. Now I’m thinking about trains.

utterance.speaker: Raj

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hmm? Oh, I’m sorry. I was somewhere else.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Lucky bastard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now I’m thinking about Jell-O.

utterance.speaker: Raj

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s a Bernadette thing.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, no. I hope everything’s okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Whatever it is, we’re here for you. You can tell us anything.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah. Good or devastating.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m gonna ask her to marry me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Marry you?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah. I just need to figure out the right time to pop the question.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, I’d wait.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No rush, no rush.

utterance.speaker: Howard (phone rings)
utterance.content: Oh, great. It’s my cousin David about the ring. Hey, David, what’d you find? Oh, sure, a half a carat’s fine. Her freakishly small hands make anything look big. It’s one of the reasons I love her.

utterance.speaker: Leonard

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I know. It’ll be awful.

utterance.content: Why are you smiling?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, Raj, why?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Uh, a smile means something different in my country. You know, tears of joy, smile of sadness. India’s a goofy place.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’m back to trains. Woo-woo.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Did I tell you our lab got a grant to study addiction?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Fascinating work. I recently trained a capuchin monkey to smoke cigarettes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Have you learned anything?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Yes. He looks much cooler than the non-smoking monkeys. Although it’s not much of a contest. The other monkeys just sit around and masturbate.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If you don’t mind, I’d like to stop listening to you and start talking.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: By all means.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Howard has announced his intention to propose marriage to Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I don’t understand. The original piece of gossip indicated an impending breakup.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know. The group consensus is that his proposal will be met with an humiliating, soul-crushing rejection. Everyone was set a-twitter. Although oddly, no one tweeted.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It’s not surprising that the story has captured the attention of our little circle of friends. Are you familiar with meme theory?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m familiar with everything, but go on.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Meme theory suggests that items of gossip are like living things that seek to reproduce using humans as their host.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m no stranger to memetic epidemiology. At Johnson Elementary School, the phrase Shelly Cooper’s a smelly pooper spread like wildfire.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I should think so. That’s gold.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Your meme hypothesis does intrigue me. How might we examine this more closely?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Do you have any ethical qualms regarding human experimentation?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s one of the few forms of interaction with people that I don’t find repellent.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We need to fabricate a tantalizing piece of gossip.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And a second non-tantalizing piece to use as a control.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Then we’ll track its progress through our social group and interpret the results through the competing academic prisms of memetic theory, algebraic gossip and epidemiology.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Look at you, getting me to engage in the social sciences. You’re a vixen, Amy Farrah Fowler.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, hey, Amy. What’s up?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon and I engaged in sexual intercourse. In other news, I’m thinking of starting an herb garden. Mum’s the word. Gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette

utterance.speaker: Bernadette

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, I know that. How do you know that?

utterance.speaker: Raj

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, that gossipy bitch! No offense.
